awd_titl_txt: WORKSHOP:  EXPLORING NEW DIMENSIONS OF FOREST ECOSYSTEMS WITH STRUCTURAL DIVERSITY
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists have long known that biodiversity and ecosystem structure are important for forests. However, these concepts are mostly studied in isolation. This has resulted in a limited understanding of how they relate to each other and to forest function. Forest physical structure can now be easily measured because of advances in remote sensing and computer science. The term 'structural diversity' describes the combination of structure and biodiversity within complex ecosystems, capitalizing on decades of ecology research. Structural diversity estimates niche space for species in ecosystems, and it may link more closely to ecosystem function than biodiversity. Funding will support a workshop designed to advance the science on structural diversity and forest ecosystem function. The group will identify urgent, new research questions and synthesize two areas of biology: biodiversity and remote sensing of ecosystem structure. The workshop will use data from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON). Recruitment of early career and underrepresented minority scientists will increase adoption of NEON data in scientific research. This will address a critical need from the 2018 NEON Community Engagement Assessment Report. It also responds to the NEON Strategic Plan by reaching current users and expanding future use.

The application of structural diversity within ecological research is limited by its underdeveloped theoretical framework and a lack of prioritized research questions. This workshop, held in partnership with Battelle and NEON, Inc., will explore foundational questions, identify key knowledge gaps, and prioritize future directions for this new field. The goals of this workshop are to 1) establish an interdisciplinary consensus definition of 'structural diversity', 2) identify key research questions about structural diversity and its relationship to ecological processes to be addressed in the next five years and the knowledge gaps needed to be filled to answer these questions, 3) provide training for early career scientists to measure structural diversity using NEON remote sensing data products. The workshop will bring together scientists with interdisciplinary perspectives of forest ecology and from underrepresented groups to further increase its impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In, 2019, Purdue University received a $93,481.00 award entitled, “Workshop: Exploring new dimensions of forest ecosystems with structural diversity”. The goal was to use a workshop format to advance the science on structural diversity and forest ecosystem function by:

Interdisciplinary consensus definition of 'structural diversity’: Previous definitions of structural diversity and similar terminology, had been disjointed in the literature. A group of over 70 interdisciplinary scientists joined a virtual workshop in May 2020 to contribute to a new description of structural diversity. A working group of 21 scientists prepared a manuscript for publication in a special issue "Exploring New Dimensions of Ecosystem Structural Diversity" that describes this consensus framework for structural diversity.

Key research questions about structural diversity in ecology: Two workshops and a special issue in a top ecological journal were used to identify the critical research gaps in the field and to showcase ongoing research from many early-career scientists on structural diversity. Over 70 participants in a May 2020 workshop, including 69% early-career scientists (student to assistant professor), identified the critical questions that should be addressed next on structural diversity and its importance in ecology. Many of the workshop participants contributed to seven manuscripts that are accepted or have revisions under review for a peer-reviewed special issue on the topic. Six of the seven manuscripts were led by early-career scientists and many students participated in the special issue. A small in-person workshop was held at the University of Texas of El Paso in May 2022 to address a gap in our theoretical understanding of the cross-ecosystem controls of structural diversity that is limited due to inconsistent approaches for measuring it. 71% of the participants were early-career and they had expertise in different ecosystem (microbial - marine – tundra – dryland – forest - urban). Finally, three peer-review articles have been published, two accepted, and 10 presentations related to the topic of structural diversity have been given to date. 

Early career training using NEON data to measure structural diversity: Online NEON training materials were provided on www.neonscience.org to provide early-career trainings on how to measure structural diversity using NEON LiDAR in different forest sites. The second workshop group is preparing guidelines for measuring structural diversity across different ecosystems and will release example remote sensing datasets and corresponding code with a peer-reviewed publication in the near future. 

Summary: The participation of interdisciplinary and early-career scientists at two workshops and in a special issue on "Exploring New Dimensions of Ecosystem Structural Diversity" have made and disseminated substantial progress on establishing a framework, critical research questions, practical applications to management, and remote sensing training resources in the new field of structural diversity.
